newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israel says twin Gaza blasts are suicide attacks.
newsitem.headline: Israel says twin Gaza blasts are suicide attacks.

text.p: Two bombs exploded in the Gaza Strip on Tuesday in what Israel said were Palestinian suicide attacks aimed at Jewish settlers.

The Israeli army said two bombers died in separate attacks, one of which wounded five Arabs in a taxi. No Israelis were hurt. Palestinian police could not confirm whether the two men had blown themselves up deliberately.

The Islamic fundamentalist group Hamas denied it was behind the explosions and accused Israel of ordering the blasts to sour relations between Hamas and Yasser Arafat's self-rule Palestinian Authority.

The blasts came against a backdrop of stalled Israeli-PLO peace talks and Israeli accusations that Arafat has failed to curb Palestinian militants in the areas of the West Bank and Gaza Strip that he controls.
Arafat said one man had blown himself up and accused Israeli soldiers of shooting the other.

"This morning, one blew himself up on the road. In (sic) the same time an Israeli jeep opened fire on two taxis. One Palestinian was killed and five were injured," Arafat told a meeting of foreign donors in Gaza.
"What will be the reaction from our side, to control more and more? For every pressure there is a reaction. This is natural law," Arafat said.
An Israeli army spokesman rejected Arafat's account.
"As regards Chairman Arafat's remark, it is absolutely incorrect. There were two suicide attacks and two bombs," the spokesman told Reuters.
Israeli military sources said one of the dead men wore a suicide bomb belt, and the other wore the uniform of the Palestinian police.
A senior Palestinian security official said police were trying to identify the dead men in an attempt to "clear the ambiguities" surrounding their deaths.

Earlier, other Palestinian police officials had said that a man with five kg (11 lb) of explosives on his back blew himself up on the side of the road at 7 a.m. (0400 GMT) about two km (1.5 miles) from the Jewish settlement of Netzarim south of Gaza City.

"We doubt that they were suicide bombings and we are checking the two explosions. No Israelis were in the area and there are no holes in the ground," Gaza police commander, Major-General Abdel-Razik Majaida, said.

In the second blast about two km (1.5 miles) from Kfar Darom near the Palestinian refugee camp of Deir al-Balah, the presumed bomber was also standing beside the road, Palestinian police said, adding the five Palestinians were wounded in this explosion.
In the past both Jewish settlements have been the focus of Palestinian attacks.
Hamas official Sayed Abu Musameh blamed Israel for the blasts.

"This bombing was done by the Israeli intelligence and its (Palestinian) collaborators in an attempt to create an internal problem between the Islamic movement and the Palestinian Authority," he told Reuters.
Last month Hamas claimed responsibility for a suicide bombing in Tel Aviv in which three Israeli women were killed.

In a separate incident on Tuesday, a Palestinian was shot dead in the West Bank city of Hebron. Israeli police said the man ran into a policeman with his car at an Israeli roadblock near the West Bank Jewish settlement of Kiryat Arba. They said the policeman opened fire, wounding a passenger.
A Palestinian witness said he ran to the road on hearing a shot and found a man, wearing pyjamas and slippers, lying in the road. He did not have a car. Clashes erupted nearby after the shooting.

Israeli-Palestinian relations have plunged into crisis since Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu broke ground on a Jewish settlement in Arab East Jerusalem last month. Israeli soldiers have clashed for 13 straight days with stone-throwing Palestinian protesters in the West Bank.
Both Gaza explosions occurred around 7 a.m., about the time Israeli children leave two nearby Jewish settlements on buses for school, Jewish settlers said.
There was no explanation why the two explosions occurred when they did, far from any Israeli soldiers or civilians.
Israeli radio stations suggested that two suicide bombers had mistakenly blown themselves up before their intended time.
Jewish settlers in the area said a PLO police outpost near the Netzarim explosion was unmanned at the time of the blast.
They claimed this showed there was collusion between the Palestinian Authority and the planners of the explosion.
